subquestion.question: Where do you want the care to take place?
What language do you want your child to be taught in?

answers.answer: Full immersion in Te Reo Māori

options.heading: Puna Reo
options.text: Puna Reo are full immersion Te Reo Māori education and care services.
conditions: Puna Reo have at least 50% qualified teachers on staff
There are only thirteen Puna Reo in Aotearoa, compared to 460 Kōhanga Reo, so there may not be one near you

options.heading: Te Kōhanga Reo
options.text: Te kōhanga reo is a full immersion te reo Māori whānau programme. This means more than 80% of the communication is in te reo Māori.
conditions: Ages: birth until age six
Sessions: held regularly for no more than 4 hours per day
Staff: parents and whānau volunteers
Expectations of you and your whānau: Whānau are key and must have a vested interest in the promotion and survival of the Māori language and its cultural practices.

Kōhanga Reo is not only a journey for the child but for the whole family. Kōhanga Reo offers courses for parents, through whānau learning as well as professional development for Kaiako(teachers), kaimahi and parents.
In New Zealand, there are 440 Te Kōhanga Reo.

links.text: Find a Kōhanga Reo near you

options.heading: Ngā Puna Kōhungahunga
options.text:
Ngā puna kōhungahunga are a type of playgroup that focus on learning te reo Māori and tikanga. Learning may be in both English and te reo or in te reo only.

The main aim of a puna kōhungahunga is for whānau to get together and encourage tamariki to learn about the tikanga and reo of tangata whenua of the area, and to provide a learning environment that responds to the interests and learning needs of individual tamariki.
conditions: Sessions: held regularly for no more than 4 hours per day
Staff: parents and whānau volunteers
Expectations of you and your whānau: More than half the children attending must have a parent there with them.

options.heading: Kindergarten
conditions: Ages: Most cater for children aged between two-and-a-half and five years.
Sessions: Most have morning and afternoon sessions, but others provide extended sessions or all day education and care
Staff: Qualified and registered teachers.

Expectations of you and your whānau: Local (parent/whānau) committees support teachers in each kindergarten, and raise local funds and resources to support the kindergarten. Parents are also asked for financial donations.
Although the teachers have responsibility for the programme, you and your whānau are encouraged to participate in programmes, talk with staff, ask questions and offer information about your child.
In New Zealand, there are 661 kindergartens.

answers.answer: I need flexible time to work with my work or study

options.heading: Education and care services
options.text:
Education and care services offer a variety of services and philosophies. These include:

  • all-day and part-day services;
  • sessional services that have sessions of a few hours per day or week;
  • Pacific language centres;
  • Montessori
  • Rudolf Steiner (Waldorf)
  • privately owned centres;
  • community-owned centres; and
  • ancillary centres attached to a business or an organisation (for example a gym crèche).
conditions: Staff: Qualified and registered teacher. There should also be enough other educators with a range of qualifications and experience to ensure a safe learning environment for children.
Expectations of you and your whānau: Parents/whānau usually pay fees for their child to attend education and care services. Parents are sometimes involved in the management of the centre.

options.heading: Montessori
options.text: Montessori early childhood centres focus on your child’s learning and self-discovery, and not on teachers “teaching”. This is achieved through adult observation and your child’s creative exploration of the Montessori materials and activities, not on plastic toys, puzzles, workbooks, etc.
conditions: Ages: Ages: birth to six years old, although a suggested approach is a three-year programme, from around three to six years of age. The children in a class are a mix of ages - e.g. not just three and four-year-olds.
Sessions: Most have morning and afternoon sessions, but others provide extended sessions or all day education and care
Staff: Qualified Montessori teacher
Expectations of you and your whānau: Parent involvement is welcomed for specific times and community activities.
In New Zealand, there are nearly 200 Montessori early childhood centres.

links.text: Find out more about Montessori for children up to three years old
Find out more about Montessori for children between three and six years old
Find a Montessori centre near you

options.heading: Rudolf Steiner (Waldorf) centres
options.text: Steiner/Waldorf education addresses the whole child in the areas of thinking, feeling and willing through a play-based curriculum. The use of computers, electronic media, and television are therefore discouraged for young children.
conditions: Staff: Qualified and registered teacher
Expectations of you and your whānau: Most Steiner education centres require regular donations.
In New Zealand, there are 11 Steiner schools with attached kindergartens and 12 stand-alone kindergartens and early childhood centres

links.text: Find out more about Steiner education
Find a Steiner centre near you

options.heading: Aoga
options.text: A’oga are Samoan education and care services. They can either be full immersion (more than 80% of the communication is in the desired language), bilingual (with English), or multilingual (including English and te reo Māori).
conditions: Sessions: all-day or part-day education and care
Staff: Qualified and registered teacher
Expectations of you and your whānau: You may be asked for a donation to support the group.
In New Zealand, there are 16 aoga.

options.heading: Akoteu
options.text: Akoteu are Tongan education and care services. They can either be full immersion (more than 80% of the communication is in the desired language), bilingual (with English), or multilingual (including English and te reo Māori).
conditions: Sessions: all-day or part-day education and care
Staff: Qualified and registered teacher
Expectations of you and your whānau: You may be asked for a donation to support the group.
In New Zealand, there are 12 akoteu.

options.heading: Home-based education and care
options.text: Home-based education and care is provided for groups of up to 4 children.
conditions: Ages: birth to 5 years
Sessions: all-day or part-day education and care

Staff: yourself (or an adult educator) in your own home. As an educator, you must belong to a licensed home-based care network. Qualified and registered teachers are employed as coordinators to support you. The home-based network coordinator visits each home regularly to check on children’s safety, wellbeing and learning.
Expectations of you and your whānau: It is normal for you to be charged fees for your child's attendance.

answers.answer: At the home of the carer

options.heading: Home-based education and care
options.text: Home-based education and care is provided for groups of up to 4 children.
conditions: Ages: birth to 5 years
Sessions: all-day or part-day education and care

Staff: an adult educator in their home. Each educator must belong to a licensed home-based care network. Qualified and registered teachers are employed as coordinators to support the educators within each network. The home-based network coordinator visits each home regularly to check on children’s safety, wellbeing and learning.
Expectations of you and your whānau: It is normal for you to be charged fees for your child's attendance.
In New Zealand, there are 421 home-based education and care centres.

answers.answer: I can sometimes stay with my child and help out with care

options.heading: Playcentre
options.text: Playcentres are parent cooperatives that offer learning through play.
conditions: Ages: birth to school age
Staff: parents, whānau and caregivers

Expectations of you and your whānau: You are responsible for how the centre is managed and operated. Parents become members of their playcentre and most pay low fees to attend. Playcentres also provide educational programmes for parents/whānau to learn alongside their children. These programmes increase parents’ understanding of how children learn and develop, and can lead to playcentre and early childhood qualifications.
In New Zealand, there are 404 playcentres

options.heading: Te Kura (the Correspondence School)
options.text: Te Kura (the Correspondence School) offers learning programmes for children aged between 3 and 5 years who can't attend an early learning service or kōhanga reo. Te Kura's early learning educators work with you to meet your child's early learning needs. They also have a range of books, puzzles, games and art materials you can borrow.
